fact: Madam C.J. Walker, born Sarah Breedlove, was the first self-made millionaire in America, thanks to her hair care and beauty products for black women in the early 1900s.
The first black-owned and operated TV station in the United States was WGPR-TV in Detroit, Michigan, founded in 1975.
Black Wall Street was a thriving community of black-owned businesses in Tulsa, Oklahoma in the early 20th century, until it was destroyed in the Tulsa Race Massacre of 1921.
Essence Communications, the parent company of Essence magazine, was founded in 1968 by black business owners as a way to uplift and empower black women.
The National Black Chamber of Commerce was founded in 1993 to promote and support black-owned businesses across the United States.
Black-owned bookstores, such as Marcus Books in Oakland, California, have long been important cultural and intellectual hubs for black communities.
The first black-owned bank in the United States, the Savings Bank of the Grand Fountain United Order of True Reformers, was founded in Richmond, Virginia in 1888.

Black-owned beauty supply stores, such as the Atlanta-based chain Nubian Hueman, have become popular in recent years as a way for black entrepreneurs to offer products tailored to black hair and skin.
The first black-owned radio station in the United States, WERD in Atlanta, Georgia, was founded in 1949 by Jesse B. Blayton, Sr.
In the 1960s, the Black Panther Party launched several successful business ventures, including a free breakfast program for children and a newspaper called The Black Panther.
Black-owned record labels, such as Motown Records and Def Jam Recordings, have played a major role in shaping the sound of popular music in the United States.
The National Minority Supplier Development Council, founded in 1972, helps black-owned businesses connect with corporations and government agencies looking to diversify their supply chains.
The Atlanta Life Insurance Company, founded in 1905 by Alonzo Herndon, was one of the largest and most successful black-owned insurance companies in the United States in the early 20th century.
Black-owned restaurants, such as Sylvia's in Harlem, New York and Dooky Chase's in New Orleans, have played an important role in preserving and celebrating black culinary traditions.
